Bottom line: Soaring prescription drug prices are crushing Americans at the pharmacy counter, driving up health insurance premiums, and creating unaffordable costs for taxpayers. 

We can't pass the #LowerDrugCosts Now Act quickly enough.

1.14 million Pennsylvanians live with diabetes. Over the past decade, the price of insulin has increased 197%. What's the use of lifesaving medication if the people who need it can't afford it? 

Under #HR3, PA residents could spend 3.5x less on the insulin they need to survive.

I'm done watching families in my community have to choose between out of control prescription drug costs & their health. 

3 in 10 adults reported not taking their medicines as prescribed at some point in the past year b/c of cost. #HR3 would help millions of Pennsylvanians.

Far too often Americans choose to ration their meds to make them last longer, even if it means risking their health.
 
1 in 4 insulin-dependent diabetics ration their insulin due to cost and sadly Monique was among that 25%. You can read her story here 👇 https://www.mcall.com/health/mc-hea-insulin-rationing-poverty-20191114-2a5yaasyrbaute57t6dyo3leam-story.html …

Medication insecurity is the inability to pay for prescribed meds at least once in the past 12mo. And it impacts nearly 25% of Americans. On top of that, nearly 90% of US adults say prescription drug costs are too high. Passing #HR3 would be the first step in ending this crisis.

1 in 8 American adults know at least one friend or family member who, in the last 5 years, died after not receiving treatment because they couldn’t afford it. Drug prices should never be so high that people can’t afford life-saving treatment.

According to a Gallup poll released this week, high prescription drug prices are hurting Americans more than ever before. To make matters worse, people of color, members of lower-income households, people younger than 45, and women are disproportionately affected by this crisis.
